items.content_html:
Description

I created an advent calendar-themed SVG tutorial. I plan to update it in the future with more interactive examples (integrate this demo for instance), but first I wanted to see if it finds its audience this way.

Is it too soon to link it in the MDN docs? Also, if you have any ideas on how to find its audience, and rank it in Google, or have any feedback, I'd highly appreciate it.

Motivation

I'm working on an interactive SVG tutorial and I'd like to find its audience.

Additional details

-

Related issues and pull requests

-
items.title: SVG: Add link to svg-tutorial.com

items.content_html:
This PR removes the list of events per interface because:

  • it duplicates information that is in each interface now (it wasn't initially the case)
  • it is incomplete
  • it is impossible to maintain (far too complex)

I also fixed a broken link (not listed as a flaw) in the table for Performance API: We now have an overview page that groups all the related specs. It is shorter, more convenient, and will always be up-to-date.
items.title: Remove tedious, incomplete and unmaintained list of events per interface

items.content_html:
Added the initial content for the index.md file, including information on HTML form attributes.

Description

✍️ Added comprehensive documentation for HTML form attributes in the index.md file, covering key attributes such as action, method, enctype, target, name, autocomplete, and novalidate. The documentation includes usage examples and explanations of each attribute.

Motivation

❓ The addition of this documentation aims to enhance the understanding of HTML form attributes for developers and facilitate the creation of well-structured and accessible web forms.

Additional details

🔗 This contribution is in response to and resolves issue #404 in the "mdn/mdn" repository.
items.title: Add HTML Form Attribute Documentation

items.content_html:
FF122 adds support to get whether an element's rendering is been skipped due to content-visibility:auto being set. The support is a new property of the Element.checkVisibility() options parameter object named contentVisibilityAuto. There are also two other options opacityProperty and visibilityProperty created as aliases of other existing options in the same bugzilla https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1859852

There are two complications:

  • The CSS that allows content to be skipped is in preview. That means that checkVisibility() will always return the correct value even now (because it will be false if not in preview).
  • The other two properties are not related to the content-visibility features.

So I think these new options are effectively released, but I'm not sure, and I'm in discussion with BCD/engineering.

For now I have put all these options in experimental features associated with the content-visibility:auto information. I would have some of this information here in any case. But I may need to move some of it to release notes depending on how the discussion falls out with BCD team.

Other docs work for this can be tracked in #31107
items.title: FF122 ExprFeatre: Element.checkVisibility() supports options.contentVisibilityAuto

items.content_html:
FF122 ships support for ArrayBuffer.prototype.transfer(), ArrayBuffer.prototype.transferToFixedLength(),ArrayBuffer.prototype.detached in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1865103

This removes the experimental status markup. Other docs look fine.

Related docs work can be tracked in #31101
items.title: FF122 ArrayBuffer.transfer() and friends - remove experimental tagging

items.content_html:
FF122 supports the Intl/Segmenter in nightly in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1423593.

This updates the Experimental features page with that information.

Related docs work can be tracked in #31098
items.title: Ff122 expr intl segmenter

items.content_html:
FF122 adds support for the Screen Wake Lock API in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1589554 in Nightly.

As part of the release work, this is a quick subedit for the Screen Wake Lock API docs. Most of it is just layout change. There are a few minor parts where I have added better cross linking.

Related docs work can be tracked in #31112
items.title: Screen Wake Lock API subedit

items.content_html:
FF122 adds support for the Screen Wake Lock API in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1589554 in Nightly. This adds experimental features update.

Related docs work can be tracked in #31112
items.title: FF122 ExprFeature: Screen Wake Lock

items.title: React: export default App

items.content_html:
This is an attempt at a fix for #22974.

I agree that the current bit could mislead people into thinking that just putting a long-running function on the same thread in a sync wrapper would fix the responsiveness problem.

But I also think async is a necessary part of the solution, as it gives the caller a mechanism to handle the result of the operation, without them having to wait for it.

Happy to work on this some more if we can improve it.
items.title: Fix issue 22974: clarify sync function problem
